poem:
Route 21 rumbles through cracked asphalt veins,  
steel lungs exhaling diesel mist at every stoplight.  
Late-night neon pools in tire treads,  
and the rumble carries stories of midnight deals.  

Passengers settle into vinyl seats,  
fingers grazing cold metal grips,  
eyes half-lidded against the thrum.  
A stray possum darts across the road—  
the bus doesn’t pause, its wheels keep faith  
with the strict calendar of departures and arrivals.  

The driver’s voice crackles over the intercom,  
spinning a yarn about a ghost train in the subway tunnels,  
where iron tracks bend to the will of a single whistle.  
He claims he once outraced a storm,  
leaving thunder in his rearview mirror.  
No one asks for proof.  

Outside, the city breathes in jagged rhythms:  
sirens singing off-key,  
dripping gutters gushing secrets,  
and neon adverts flickering like distant beacons.  
Under flickering streetlamps,  
the route’s silhouette cuts a straight line—  
unyielding, methodical, relentless in its promise:  
to go where the map says go,  
to tell the tale however tall,  
and to keep rolling,  
even when the night begs it to stop.
